zewt.  Acknowledged.
’twas two nights after srcset, and all through the chat
not a creature was stirring, not even a... sig cat
the use cases were hung on anything near
in hopes that efficient scalable image delivery over the web ...
... would soon be here
developers were nestled, all snug in their beds
visions of media queries still danced in their heads
implementers too, not impressed
had just settled down for a long spring rest ...

what's the reason appendix sections in CSS specs aren't numbered (like A.1, A.2, etc.)?
is is that the numbering scheme is ugly?
heycam: at least some CSS appendix naming forms a joke, but maybe that was only for CSS 2 and 2.1
hsivonen, ah yes, for the appendix letters
hsivonen, though notice how if you jump to the bottom of http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/cover.html that appendix sections get numbers while those in http://dev.w3.org/csswg/css3-text/#contents don't
maybe the letter thing is for CSS 2/2.1 only

is there a makefile for the whatwg "complete" version somewhere?
No
k
Most of Hixie's pipeline is closed source because it is very environment specific
But the complete version of the spec might be relatively easy to make since it is the most, well, complete
http://pimpmyspec.net/ + the right options might get you a lot of the way there
Of course, the output is conveniently provided, so I wonder what the motivation is ;)

in an async algorithm, are all observable changes queued tasks?
e.g. manipulation of the fullscreen elemetn stack
has the feeling nobody really cares about task queues
well, task queues are really just partial order guarantees, right?
(so if an implementation orders *all* queued events, they mostly don't have to care about them)

Morning all. :D

Philip`: let's not forget the support forum, er.. mailing list.
annevk: E for example
annevk: you know, like FF and DM were plain ASCII before euro
heh
apparently our former currency didn't have a code point http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florin_sign
On (at least) UK keyboard layouts, the € symbol is stuffed pretty inelegantly into a spare corner of the 4/$ key, which doesn't seem like great design
(The ¬`| key is the only other one that typically follows that pattern)
hsivonen: the French had U+20A3 ₣ but also used F/FF indeed
some more browsing reveals that http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azerbaijani_manat does not have a Unicode symbol while they do have a distinct sign
weird

http://www.tcmb.gov.tr/yeni/iletisimgm/TurkishLira.php - "The upward pointing parallel lines symbolize the "steadily rising value" of the Turkish lira and the Turkish economy." - does that mean they'll redesign the currency symbol if their economy collapses?
heh, they got this one because it devalued so much
before euro, Finland use an ASCII-only currency abbreviation "mk" and it worked great
finds £ annoying with just ASCII — going for GBP as a suffix just seems weird
gsnedders: Use "lb" instead
hsivonen: I typically use the three-letter code because that works great in Google :)
1000 pen in eur please

in other news, it's terribly inconvenient that Ubuntu 12.04 ships Wine64 and the wine binary that ships with CrossOver (which looks like 32-bit Windows even on 64-bit host) is incompatible with winetricks
of course, CrossOver is supposed to make winetricks unnecessary, but CrossOver is broken
scrolls up and reads about currency symbols.
There's definitely quite a variety of ways that folks publish currency amounts on the web.
The three-letter code as annevk suggests is probably the easiest to both publish and search for.
But not what every locality is used to seeing - so...

anwyay - if anyone is interested in either reading more on currency publishing practices on the web or has further real world examples to add, please take a look at: http://microformats.org/wiki/currency-examples
and currency related formats respectively: http://microformats.org/wiki/currency-formats
